title: Prosody Labeling with Phoneme-BERT and Speech Foundation Models
author: Tomoki Koriyama (CyberAgent, Japan)
relevance_why: This paper introduces an innovative automatic prosody annotation model that combines speech and linguistic foundation models, which could enhance audio processing tasks relevant to Haohe Liu's research in text-to-audio generation and audio quality enhancement.
background: Automatic annotation of prosodic labels in speech to improve the quality and control of text-to-speech systems, particularly for Japanese language prosody.
contribution: This paper introduces a model that combines linguistic and acoustic features for phoneme-level prosodic label prediction for speech synthesis applications, achieving high prediction accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically relied on either acoustic features alone or linguistic models separated from speech, limiting their effectiveness in accurately capturing prosody.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon these methods by utilizing a concatenated feature set from both types of models, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy significantly.

key_innovation: The proposed model leverages acoustic information from self-supervised learning models and phoneme-level linguistic features to predict prosody labels, making it adaptable and accurate for speech synthesis.
real_world_impact: The developments in accurate prosody labeling can improve the naturalness and expressiveness of synthetic speech, enhancing user experience in various applications, including virtual assistants and automated voice systems.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.phoneme-level: **Phoneme-level** refers to the analysis or processing of individual phonemes in spoken language, the smallest units of sound that distinguish words.
new_terms.self-supervised learning: **Self-supervised learning** is a type of machine learning where the model learns to represent data without explicit labels by predicting parts of the input from other parts.
